channel.title: Difference between

item.title: Difference between
item.dc:creator: @Clawz_fury lare69
item.description:
@Clawz_fury wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:2, topic:545892”]Yes, the former is just a shorthand for the latter.

The shorthand form means the entire method (between the braces) is synchronised and uses the object instance as the mutex lock. The more verbose way allows you use to use a different object as a lock and obviously gives you more control over which statements you want synchronised.

Provided the method is not time-consuming and only alters some data concurrently the shorthand way is perfectly acceptable, however if the method is time intensive, you should only use the sychronized block around statements that actually require the mutex lock.[/quote]
perfect, just the explanation I was looking for thanks

Read full topic

item.title: Difference between
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

Yes, the former is just a shorthand for the latter.

The shorthand form means the entire method (between the braces) is synchronised and uses the object instance as the mutex lock. The more verbose way allows you use to use a different object as a lock and obviously gives you more control over which statements you want synchronised.

Provided the method is not time-consuming and only alters some data concurrently the shorthand way is perfectly acceptable, however if the method is time intensive, you should only use the sychronized block around statements that actually require the mutex lock.

Read full topic

item.title: Difference between
item.dc:creator: @Clawz_fury lare69
item.description:
@Clawz_fury wrote:

public synchronized void doSomething() { ... }

public void doSomething() { synchronized(this) { ... } }

wouldn’t both of those prevent multiple threads from accessing the “…” part of the code at the same time?

Read full topic
